newsitem.title: USA: U.S. debt futures rally on data, turn very choppy.
newsitem.headline: U.S. debt futures rally on data, turn very choppy.

text.p: U.S. debt futures rallied on a weaker-than-expected jobs rise in April, with trading choppy and volume brisk early.
April jobs rose 142,000 against a forecast for a 211,000 gain, and March was revised downward to 139,000 from 175,000.
The jobless rate fell to 4.9 percent from 5.2 percent.
June Treasury bonds and September Euros rallied near two-month highs on the data then sliced their gains before drifting back toward the top of the range again.
Traders called action extremely choppy. T-bond and Eurodollar futures were trading in fast markets.
"Look at those numbers, each component is so extreme," one T-bond trader said. "Everything just completely whipsaws us," he said.

Average hourly earnings slipped to $12.14 from $12.15 and the average workweek slipped to 34.6 hours from 34.9 in March. Overtime hours rose to 5.0 from 4.9 and manufacturing hours inched up to 42.2 from 42.1.
September Euros popped above resistance at 93.90 and broke above the 200-day moving average at 93.93.
But Euros soon erased their gains and turned lower.
"They ran up really good, but we had a big sell off as all the locals turned sellers," a Eurodollar trader said. September made an attempt to recover before slipping into negative territory.
By 0807 CDT/1307 GMT, debt futures turned mixed.

"We had buying coming off the lower-than-expected payrolls numbers and the hourly earnings, but I think the market has done so much this week that I think you're seeing some profit-taking," said John Kadich, floor analyst with Dean Witter.
Fast market status was lifted from the markets.
He said traders were beginning to focus on the much weaker-than-expected jobless rate of 4.9 percent.
"The question now is when does low unemployment hit the market," Kadich said.
As debt futures headed back near Thursday's closing levels, activity tapered off some, with action still choppy, traders said.

"We're kind of mulling through the numbers," said Kurt Fraim, futures analyst with Aubrey G. Lanston. He pegged resistance now in June T-bonds at 109-28/32 and in 10-year notes at 107-16/32, two levels breached on the rally.
He pegged the next significant support in June 10-year notes at 105-16/32 and at 108-12/32 in T-bonds.

At 0826 CDT/1326 GMT, June T-bonds were up 2/32 to 109-23/32, 10-year notes rose 1/32 to 107-6/32, September T-bills were flat at 94.460, September Eurodollars were down 0.010 at 93.875 and December Eurodollars were 0.005 higher at 93.660. ((DerivativesDesk(312)408-8750)) E-mail:derivatives@reuters.com
